MainHeading.Title: Written Answers - Teaching Posts.

Qst.Quest: the measures, if any, he is introducing to attract more physics and chemistry graduates into teaching, to retain physics and chemistry graduates in teaching; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

if he has satisfied himself that sufficient points are allocated to physics and chemistry in the leaving certificate examination; the proposals, if any, he has in this regard; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education and Science (Mr. Martin) Micheál Martin
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Education and Science (Mr. Martin)
Speaker.P: I propose to take Questions Nos. 26 and 65 together.

Earlier this year I announced that I was increasing the number of places available on the higher diploma in education courses for the 1998-99 academic year from 800 to 940. Of these additional places, 100 are specifically for teachers of Irish, religion, Italian, Spanish and key sciences. I am concerned with the decrease in the numbers taking physics and chemistry at leaving certificate level. However, a number of measures already taken or planned should increase the uptake in the numbers opting for these subjects at leaving certificate level and help retain physics and chemistry graduates in teaching. These measures include the IT 2000 initiative, the science programme in the new primary curriculum, the introduction of new syllabi in physics and chemistry from September 2000 and the general awareness initiatives under way to advise young people of the employment potential in science and technology related areas.

MainHeading.P: The allocation of points for leaving certificate subjects for entry to third level institutions is a matter for the institutions involved. The CAO is a limited company set up by the third level institutions as an administrative mechanism for dealing with applications and admissions and the CAO operates a common points system. I set up the Commission on the Points System in October 1997. An Action Programme for the Millennium sets out as a key priority the appointment of a such a group to examine the points system. I have set out in the terms of reference for the commission that it should review the present system of entry to third level institutions and make any recommendation that it considers appropriate. The commission has recently published its consultative document and aims to produce its final report in late spring/early summer 1999.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers - Higher Education Grants.

Qst.Quest: if his Department has an estimate of the cost of maintaining a student at third level college; the way in which this compares with the maintenance grant payable by his Department; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education and Science (Mr. Martin) Micheál Martin
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Education and Science (Mr. Martin)
Speaker.P: My Department has not carried out research into the cost of maintaining a student at a third level college. The statutory framework for the scheme, as set out in the Local Authorities (Higher Education Grants) Acts, 1968 to 1992, provides for higher education grants in order to assist students to attend full-time third level education. For the 1998-99 academic year, the rates of the maintenance grants payable are set at £1,652, at the non-adjacent rate and £660, at the adjacent rate. I am aware of some concern regarding the level of the grants however, I would point out improvements in this regard can only be considered in the light of overall resource constraints and other competing needs in the education sector.

The Deputy will be interested to note that some 60 per cent of certificate and diploma students in the technological sector and 40 per cent of students in the university sector are eligible for maintenance grants. In the 1996-97 academic year, almost 48,000 students received grants under these schemes. The 1996 cost of the schemes was £91 million.

It has been the practice in recent years to increase maintenance grants in line with inflation as measured by the change in the consumer price index for the period mid February to mid February each year. The inflation figure as provided by the Central Statistics Office for the period mid February 1997 to mid February 1998 was 1.7 per cent. The value of the maintenance grant was therefore increased by 1.7 per cent for the 1998-9 academic year.

It has also been the practice in recent years to increase the reckonable income limits in line with movements in the average industrial wage. The figures are provided by the Central Statistics Office and are computed in each case to March of the previous year. The average industrial wage increase for the period March 1996 to March 1997 was 3.2 per cent. The reckonable income limits for the 1998-99 academic year were therefore increased by 3.2 per cent. This increase was also applied to the allowance by which the income limits may be increased in respect of other family members pursuing a course of study. The definition of eligible courses in this regard has also been extended.

MainHeading.P: I am committed to ongoing improvements in the third level student support schemes, including increasing the value of maintenance grants and increasing the income limits as resources permit. My priority in relation to the area of student support has been to honour the commitment given in the programme for Government, An Action Programme for the Millennium to introduce equitable support for students attending PLC courses. I have honoured that commitment by way of introducing a maintenance grants scheme for students attending post leaving certificate courses. The scheme was issued to vocational education committees in August and it is anticipated that the first payment to students, which will be retrospective to September, will be made not later than January 1999. The grants payable under this scheme will be at the same level as the third level maintenance grants.

As I have said before, I have identified the creation of additional third level places as my priority at third level and to this end I have already increased by 8,000 the number of student places available at third level.

Qst.Quest: if he will grant approval to Ballygunner National School, Ballygunner, Waterford, to seek tenders for the proposed new extension to the school in view of the large number of children seeking entry in September 1999.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education and Science (Mr. Martin) Micheál Martin
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Education and Science (Mr. Martin)
Speaker.P: Architectural planning for the new extension at Ballygunner is being handled by the school's own consultant architect. In the case of all capital projects involving major expenditure of public funds, my Department's architectural service approves the detailed design and the tender documentation in order to ensure that all aspects of a design are finalised satisfactorily. This process avoids delays and increased costs later. The school manager has been requested to submit the detailed design and tender documentation in respect of the extension at Ballygunner National School. Provided the design complies with the building regulations, my Department will be in a position to expedite consideration of the documentation as soon as it is received. I will then take a decision on tender invitation in light of available finance at that time and other competing priorities.

Qst.Quest: if he will provide a classroom assistant for a person (details supplied) in County Cork; and if he will make a statement on the matter.
if a resource teacher will be allocated to Glasheen Girls' National School, County Cork; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education and Science (Mr. Martin) Micheál Martin
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Education and Science (Mr. Martin)
Speaker.P: I propose to take Questions Nos. 29 and 59 together.

My capacity to allocate additional resource teacher or child care assistant posts in any given year is dependent on resource availability and the level of competing demand from other special needs areas. I have to determine priorities and allocate available resources to best effect.

I recently allocated 26 resource teacher posts to national schools. These posts were allocated on the basis of priority of need. However, my Department has no record of an application for a resource teacher post from the school in question.

If the board of management of the school considers that the services of a resource teacher are required, it should make application to my Department giving details of all pupils assessed as having special needs. MainHeading.Title: Written Answers - School Curriculum.

Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Education and Science whether it is an objective of the Government to increase in the community the level of knowledge, skills and values relevant to the nature and practices of participative democracy; the plans, if any, the Government has to articulate principles of social and moral responsibility, community involvement and political literacy; and the most promising opportunities and the most pressing obstacles to the achievement of these objectives. [19106/98]

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education and Science (Mr. Martin) Micheál Martin
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Education and Science (Mr. Martin)
Speaker.P: A new course in Civic, Social and Political Education (CSPE) was introduced in the junior cycle curriculum from September 1996. The new course is part of the core curriculum from September 1997 in all second level schools. CSPE will be examined at junior certificate level in 1999 and thereafter.

In addition, the transition year programme and the leaving certificate applied programme offer extensive opportunities for further development in this area, with an increased emphasis on interactive and experimental learning, and a strong focus on the development of social competence and social and community awareness.

MainHeading.P: Within adult and second chance education provision, a key objective is the development of the core skills, confidence and competencies necessary for economic and social participation. This is done through provision of a range of adult literacy and community education programmes, and second chance education programmes such as Youthreach and the vocational training opportunity scheme, as well as access to post-leaving certificate courses. While such programmes provide a range of vocational options, these are featured as part of an holistic approach where personal development, communications skills and empowerment are essential aspects of the approach. Within post leaving certificate courses, elective modules in social studies and political studies are available, and are nationally certified by the National Council for Vocational Awards.

Third level institutions also offer a range of certificate, diploma and degree level programmes in social and political studies, in youth and community work, in adult and community education, and in public management.

Qst.Quest: if he will ensure that funding is provided in the 1998-99 capital programme for a proposed extension and alterations to Waterpark College, County Waterford, to ensure construction commences in early 1999 in view of the fact that planning has proceeded to stage six; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education and Science (Mr. Martin) Micheál Martin
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Education and Science (Mr. Martin)
Speaker.P: In September 1998, the building unit of my Department advised the school. authorities of Waterpark College that the Stage four documentation (detailed design) for the proposed extension and refurbishment of this school had been approved.

The school authorities were also asked to instruct their design team to proceed to stage five of the project, which is the final stage of planning before the invitation of tenders. As soon as stage five has been received and examined by the technical staff of my Department, the question of inviting tenders will be considered in the light of available capital resources. While it is not possible to say when construction will commence, every effort will be made to ensure the process is completed as quickly as possible.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers - Higher Education Grants.

Qst.Quest: the proposals, if any, he has to relax the rules of the third level maintenance grant system to allow students to be funded more than once for post-graduate studies; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education and Science (Mr. Martin) Micheál Martin
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Education and Science (Mr. Martin)
Speaker.P: Under the terms of the third level student support schemes, grants are not payable to candidates who already hold a post-graduate qualification and are pursuing a second post-graduate qualification.

MainHeading.P: Any extension of the current arrangements, as suggested by the Deputy, could only be considered in the light of available resources and the competing demands within the education sector. Due to overall resource constraints I have no plans at present to relax the rules as suggested by the Deputy.
Over 3,200 students pursuing postgraduate studies were in receipt of grants under the third level student support schemes in the 1996/97 academic year.

I would also like to advise the Deputy that, in the general area of postgraduate funding, I have provided an additional £5 million for research activity in 1998. Of this additional funding £4 million has been allocated to a number of third level colleges to promote a strategic approach to the long-term development of research, £0.5 million for the Government of Ireland Scholarships for research in the Humanities and Social Sciences and the remaining £0.5 million for basic research grants under the scheme administered by Enterprise Ireland.

Qst.Quest: further to Parliamentary Questions Nos. 426 and 427 of 13 October 1998, when the review of the overall post-primary accommodation needs in Youghal, County Cork, commenced; when he expects the review to be completed; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education and Science (Mr. Martin) Micheál Martin
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Education and Science (Mr. Martin)
Speaker.P: The planning section of my Department undertook a review of postprimary school provision in Youghal a few weeks ago. Letters issued to the managements of the schools on 13 October last, seeking their views in the matter. When responses are received, arrangements will be made to meet with the school managements as soon as possible.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers - Autism Services.

Qst.Quest: the number of students with autism known to his Department in each county; the number of these students in each county without an education service; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education and Science (Mr. Martin) Micheál Martin
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Education and Science (Mr. Martin)
Speaker.P: My Department does not have details of the number of children with autism in each county. Research data from the Eastern Health Board found a prevalence rate of 5 per 10,000 persons in the age range 0-25 who met diagnostic criteria for autism.
Children with autism have access to a range of educational support services. The precise nature of the support provided will depend on the severity of the condition in each individual case.

MainHeading.P: In some cases, children with mild features of autism can be educated in ordinary schools, with the support, where necessary, of remedial or resource teachers. Children with more serious needs have traditionally been catered for in a number of special schools and special classes, including those catering for children with mild mental handicap or emotional or behaviourial disorders.

In the 1995-96 school year a pilot programme of special services was established for children with autism. Under this programme, a number of special classes dedicated specifically to the needs of these children were established. These special classes are attached to schools located in Beech-park, Stillorgan, County Dublin and Cratloe, Ennis, County Clare. A further special class was established in St. Brigid's Special School, Dundalk, County Louth in the 1996-97 school year. A total of 46 children are catered for under the pilot programme.

In the current school year, a number of additional special classes catering specifically for children with autism have been established. Each class caters for a maximum of six children and is supported by a class teacher and a child care assistant. A special rate of capitation funding is also provided. In addition, an outreach support service is provided by the relevant health authority.
The establishment of additional classes in a number of locations is currently under active consideration in my Department.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers - Educational Projects.

Qst.Quest: if he will consider the proposal for an education task force in the north inner city of Dublin 1 in view of the fact it is an area with the lowest level of access to third level education and one of the highest drop out rates in second level education.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education and Science (Mr. Martin) Micheál Martin
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Education and Science (Mr. Martin)
Speaker.P: I assure the Deputy I am fully committed to ensuring equality of access to our third level education system for all socioeconomic groups within the community. It is generally acknowledged that the scale and concentration of disadvantage in certain areas of Dublin requires a strategic and targeted response.

Professor Patrick Clancy's report “Access to College: Patterns of Continuity and Change”, examined patterns of participation in higher education in Ireland. The report is based on a national survey of all those enrolled as new entrants to full time higher education in Autumn 1992. In this, the third and latest such national survey undertaken by Professor Clancy, it is indicated that there were nine new entrants from Dublin 1 giving an admission rate of 4.8 per cent.

MainHeading.P: As the Deputy will appreciate, the factors underlying this phenomenon go beyond the education system. Nevertheless, my Department has a range of measures in place to further the promotion of equality of access to higher education. The need for a holistic approach to promote equality rather than policies focused only on the third-level sector and on the transition from second to third level, is well established. In this regard, fuller participation in third level depends on measures to ensure access to and retention of students in full-time education at first and second levels.

The measures in place include the development of early start centres; the allocation of additional resources to schools in disadvantaged areas; the Breaking the Cycle Initiative; the home school community liaison scheme, a new initiative focused on structured pilot projects in urban and rural disadvantaged areas which test models for the development of an integrated area based co-ordination of services to cater for young people aged 8-15 at risk of early school leaving; the development of second chance education and training options through Youthreach and VTOS.

In the university sector the Higher Education Authority provided funding of £260,000 in 1996 and £475,000 in 1997 for initiatives in a number of universities specifically relating to disadvantaged students. Funding will also be provided in 1998. These initiatives build on existing programmes and involve links with second-level schools and local communities. These initiatives include supervised study facilities, extra tuition, information and advice to both pupils and parents and support teaching in subject areas. For this reason it will take some time for the effect of the programmes to be reflected in the actual numbers going on to higher education.

There are two aspects to these programmes, one involving assistance to some students to meet the points requirement for courses, enabling them to obtain a college place through the standard CAO entry procedure. The other aspect of the programmes is the special entry arrangements through which more flexible entry criteria are applied and various supports put in place for students entering by this method. Support for the university proposals is very firmly based on the intention of meeting set targets and progress reports will be submitted to the Higher Education Authority on each of the programmes funded.

The Dublin Institute of Technology has a comprehensive set of activities in which the Institute is interacting with different disadvantaged groups in Dublin city. There are currently a number of courses in place for mature students from disadvantaged backgrounds. In addition, the Dublin Institute of Technology authorities are developing arrangements for direct entry for second level students from disadvantaged backgrounds who do not meet the normal admission criteria.

My Department has approved the appointment of a full-time community education links co-ordinator in the Dublin Institute of Technology. The role of the co-ordinator is to identify, develop and co-ordinate the various initiatives of Dublin Institute of Technology in regard to disadvantaged communities in inner-city Dublin in order to increase their awareness of and participation in education, particularly at third level.

The community links programme comprises the following multi-faceted initiatives: (a) supervised study programmes: involving both disadvantaged primary and secondary school pupils and are organised by the staff and students of the Dublin Institute of Technology; (b) educational awareness programmes: involving the participation of staff and students of the Dublin Institute of Technology and disadvantaged schools in order to increase awareness of the benefits of education — second-third level — and to remove misconceived notions of third level; (c) computers-equipment: Dublin Institute of Technology has distributed redundant equipment such as computers, microscopes, audio visual equipment, to those disadvantaged groups and schools which are most in need; (d) studentships: the Dublin Institute of Technology awards studentships to financially disadvantaged pupils from inner city schools who attain a place in Dublin Institute of Technology, such students are also supported in regard to study-personal-academic problems that may arise; (e) Pathways Through Education project: Pathways Through Education is a European funded Youthstart initiative, managed jointly by the Dublin Institute of Technology and the Dublin Schools Business Partnership, the main aim of the project is to raise the self-esteem, confidence and motivation of first year pupils in three inner city disadvantaged secondary schools, the consultative group overseeing the management of the project is representative of a wide range of interests, social, economic and educational; and (f) community involvement: in 1996-97 the Dublin Institute of Technology staff developed and piloted a course in women's community development studies through the medium of art leading to a national certificate. This course is offered annually. In 1998-99 the Dublin Institute of Technology will provide a training course in basic engineering skills for young people from a disadvantaged area. The main aim of the project is to re-engage young people in education, and in so doing, to develop their selfesteem and confidence.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers - Teacher Training.

Qst.Quest: the number of in-service training courses provided to date; the value and volume of audio materials and equipment provided to date to the 250 primary schools involved in the pilot foreign language programme; and if his attention has been drawn to the serious criticism of the adequacy of the planning undertaken for this initiative.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education and Science (Mr. Martin) Micheál Martin
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Education and Science (Mr. Martin)
Speaker.P: The pilot project on modern languages has commenced in approximately 270 primary schools.

Seven project leaders have been appointed to assist and advise principals and teachers and to initiate a training programme for teachers. To date the project leaders have held 25 meetings nationwide for all those involved in the project — chairpersons, principals, class teachers and language teachers. These meetings are currently being followed up by individual school visits, a total of 126 of which have been held to date.

MainHeading.P: Preliminary lists of resource materials have been issued to schools. These lists include recommendations for multi-media materials. Schools have been advised to purchase resource materials in accordance with this list. Each participating school will be given a financial grant to assist in the purchase of materials for the project. It is proposed to issue this grant to schools before the end of this school term.

The project leaders are also in the process of producing of audio materials, which it is intended to give to teachers involved in the project. These materials will be disseminated at in-career development courses which will take place in the course of this school term.

My attention has not been drawn to any serious criticism of the adequacy of the planning for this project. Indeed I have received many congratulatory letters on my initiative in introducing modem languages to the primary sector. The Deputy will appreciate that this project has only recently commenced in schools and, as for any other new initiative, a certain adjustment period is inevitable as the project moves from the planning to the operational phase.

Qst.Quest: the steps, if any, being taken to promote the wider teaching of science in primary schools; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education and Science (Mr. Martin) Micheál Martin
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Education and Science (Mr. Martin)
Speaker.P: The National Council for Curriculum and Assessment in its review of the primary curriculum has been asked to give special emphasis to science in the social, environmental and scientific education section of the curriculum. The review is now almost complete and the revised curriculum will be presented to me for adoption early next month. The preparation for the implementation of the revised curriculum has already begun. A comprehensive programme of in-career development for teachers will support the implementation over a five year period and will begin in 1999. Training in science for primary schools will form an important part of this programme. My Department also sanctioned the appointment of additional staff to two colleges of education earlier this year in order to improve the provision in these colleges for training student teachers in primary science.

Qst.Quest: the number of teachers at first and second level granted early retirement during the 1997-98 school year; the number of such applications with his Department; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education and Science (Mr. Martin) Micheál Martin
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Education and Science (Mr. Martin)
Speaker.P: A total of 138 teachers, consisting of 41 first level teachers and 97 second level teachers, have been granted early retirement under the provisions notified to schools in connection with the 1997-98 school year. Decisions have yet to be made in the case of five applicants at first level and one at second level. In the case of one of the first level applicants, who has applied for early retirement on the grounds that he is experiencing professional difficulties in carrying out his teaching duties, the position is that my Department has received further information from the management of the school and this information is now being considered by the early retirement advisory committee.

A decision in the case of the remaining five applicants, who have applied for early retirement on the grounds that they are in schools which have posts which are surplus to requirements, is dependent on the outcome of procedures for the filling of vacancies and the redeployment of teachers who are surplus to requirements. It is expected that the outcome of these procedures will be known, and a decision on all outstanding applications will be given, during the month of November.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education and Science (Mr. Martin) Micheál Martin

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers - Vocational Training Opportunities Scheme.

Qst.Quest: the proposals, if any, he has to allow a higher percentage of single parents and persons on disability benefit to take part in VTOS courses; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education and Science (Mr. Martin) Micheál Martin
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Education and Science (Mr. Martin)
Speaker.P: The vocational training opportunities scheme, VTOS, which is supported by the European Union, was established in 1989 with the objective of providing second chance education-training opportunities for long-term unemployed people who had demonstrated through the signing on process that they were unemployed and seeking employment. It was on this basis that EU Structural Fund support was obtained.

The scheme was broadened in 1993 to include a limited number of lone parents, disabled people and spouses, for whom adult dependant allowances under the relevant schemes are paid. The number of places that may be filled from the additional categories is limited to 10 per cent of the overall total. The position regarding the 10 per cent limit is being examined in the context of an overall review of the scheme.

Qst.Quest: when a remedial teacher will be appointed to Difreen national school, Glencar, County Leitrim.

Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Education and Science (Mr. Martin)

I will continue to review needs in this area. In the event of additional remedial teacher posts becoming available for allocation, the needs of the schools to which he refers will be fully considered.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education and Science (Mr. Martin) Micheál Martin
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Education and Science (Mr. Martin)

I have provided £500,000 in the Higher Education Authority budget in 1998 for the promotion of Irish at third level.

Qst.Quest: if his attention has been drawn to the acute shortage of trained substitute teachers for primary education; and the proposals, if any, he has to offer in-service training to acting substitute teachers to strengthen their teaching skills.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education and Science (Mr. Martin) Micheál Martin
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Education and Science (Mr. Martin)
Speaker.P: Since coming into office, I have been concerned at the large number of untrained personnel working within the primary school system. For these reasons, I have introduced a range of measures which are designed to boost substantially the supply of trained teachers. Specifically, I have ensured there are over 1,000 places available in the colleges of education during the current academic year. This includes 730 students who will pursue the three year B.Ed. degree programme while 280 degree holders will be admitted to an 18 month full-time postgraduate course.

In addition, B.Ed. graduates of St. Mary's College, Belfast, who have studied Irish to honours level as an academic subject as part of their teaching qualification will be recognised as fully trained.

I am also examining the possibility of the University of Limerick providing a one year conversion course for degree holders who hold the higher diploma in education and who have either Irish as part of their degree or have Irish to grade C at the leaving certificate or its equivalent. I have further decided that from 1 September 1998, all primary degree holders who also hold the higher diploma in education will be recognised as fully trained for the purposes of providing substitution service provided that they have Irish to grade C at higher level leaving certificate standard or its equivalent.

Montessori trained teachers who successfully completed the course of three years duration at St. Nicholas, Dun Laoghaire which is recognised by the National Council for Educational Awards, will, from 1 September 1998, be granted recognition as fully trained substitutes provided that they have Irish to grade C at higher level leaving certificate or its equivalent.

Colleges of education provide opportunities for mature students to gain an appropriate teaching qualification. In-service provision relates to persons who are fully qualified as teachers, and is not intended for those who are unqualified.

Qst.Quest: the number of schools implementing the relationship and sexuality education programme in schools; if he has satisfied himself at the rate of implementation of the programme; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education and Science (Mr. Martin) Micheál Martin
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Education and Science (Mr. Martin)

MainHeading.P: I am satisfied that the necessary supports have been put in place to assist schools with the introduction of relationships and sexuality education. I recognise that schools are at different stages in implementing a programme. The information on progress being collected will provide information on the rate of implementation and will enable effective targeting of existing supports.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers - Third Level Drop-out Rates.

Qst.Quest: the progress, if any, made in establishing a database to track the level of dropouts at regional technical colleges and at university level; and if he has a system in place to ensure that comprehensive annual data will be collected in this area.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education and Science (Mr. Martin) Micheál Martin
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Education and Science (Mr. Martin)
Speaker.P: The reasons for drop-out are complex. There is no simple explanation. Factors such as motivation, capabilities and suitability are all involved. There must also be a balance between completion rates on programmes and maintaining the necessary objective standards. The challenge of maximising completion rates, consistent with maintaining appropriate standards is a matter, in the first instance, for individual universities, institutes of technology and the National Council for Educational Awards. Information is not readily available on the numbers of students who fail to complete third level courses at the universities and institutes of technology.

In relation to the university sector, the Higher Education Authority carried out a study in 1994 which indicated a completion rate of 81 per cent for those students entering in 1989-90. This rate is a high completion rate by international standards. The authority has commissioned the Educational Research Centre, St. Patrick's College, Drumcondra to undertake a further detailed study in this area.

In addition, in February 1998 the Commission on the Points System engaged a team of researchers to undertake a feasibility study of the predictive validity of the points system in relation to the intake of students into third level education in 1992. Two inter-related pieces of research were undertaken. The first part aimed to establish the feasibility of accessing material in the institutions and the second part aimed to undertake a study of sample students across the institutions. The summary of the findings to date is contained in the Consultative Process — Background Document published by the Commission on the Points System. The document indicates that 26 per cent of all students who entered college in 1992 had not been awarded any qualification from their college of entry by 1998; most had either left or failed.

MainHeading.P: A number of initiatives have been taken in the technological sector to assist the compilation of a database on attrition-drop-out rates and to develop appropriate strategies to address the issues as follows. The council of directors of the institutes of technology has established a national committee on retention and a steering committee for an action research project on retention. This national committee has set out a menu of initiatives for institutes of technology, particularly in relation to actions targeted at first year entrants in 1998. Already a number of these actions have been implemented and it is hoped this will increase retention levels in the institutes.

The action research project will undertake the following: quantify retention levels; carry out a qualitative study, which will include a survey of international literature on this topic, and inform the institutes as to the relative importance of the many factors which cause non-completion of courses; recommend to the institutes an action programme to deal with the findings. Tenders have been invited by the council for the action research project and it is hoped that the project will begin early next month.
A system has also been developed for a statistical monitoring of uncertified departures from certificate and diploma programmes and is being applied on a pilot basis in some institutes.
Other studies, in both individual institutes and in groups of institutes, have also been carried out with a view to developing actions to minimise uncertified departures.

A computerised management information systems project is being developed as part of the ongoing work to establish modern financial and administrative systems for the institutes of technology. The project has the aim of supporting the efficient and effective administration of the institutions and providing both the institutions and my Department with timely and accurate management information for a variety of purposes. This new system will provide enhanced information on completion and attrition rates and the results from the initiatives above will be fed into this project.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers - Literacy Levels.

Qst.Quest: the research, if any, his Department is involved in, or is aware of, in relation to literacy levels in primary schools; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education and Science (Mr. Martin) Micheál Martin
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Education and Science (Mr. Martin)
Speaker.P: National surveys of reading in primary schools were carried out in 1972, 1980, 1988, 1993 and 1998 by Department of Education and Science inspectors in co-operation with the Educational Research Centre with a view to monitoring levels of English reading attainment in primary schools on an ongoing basis. A random sample of pupils in fifth class was selected for testing purposes.

MainHeading.P: The findings of the 1998 survey are being processed. The reports of the 1993 and 1998 surveys will be published in a single document early in 1999.

Primary schools also participated in an international study of reading literacy in 1991. The reading literacy performance of Irish nine year olds was assessed in the International Association for the Evaluation of Educational Achievement, IEA, study of 1991. The results of this survey have been published in a number of publications by the IEA and OECD.

Qst.Quest: if he will take the necessary steps to ensure the earlier publication of the junior certificate results to allow adequate time for decisions to be made in regard to options and subject choice; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education and Science (Mr. Martin) Micheál Martin
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Education and Science (Mr. Martin)
Speaker.P: The dates on which the results of the certificate examinations are issued are a function of the timing of the actual examinations and the time required for the marking of scripts and processing of the results. While my Department will continue to make every effort to issue results as early as possible it must be recognised that there are real constraints on making any significant improvement in respect of the junior certificate if the issue date in the case of the leaving certificate is not to be affected. Given that there is a finite pool of suitably qualified examiners my Department ensures the number of examiners engaged in the leaving certificate marking process is adequate to enable the result deadlines to be met. This is possible because the later issue of junior certificate results provides some latitude in relation to providing additional time where necessary to the pool of examiners available for junior certificate marking. Ultimately the time required for the proper execution of the marking process is a direct function of the number of available examiners and the number of scripts to be examined. The Deputy will agree that priority must be given to the issue of the leaving certificate results.

Qst.Quest: the proposals, if any, he has to provide information to an organisation (details supplied) on his Department's proposals to meet the capital funding requirements of primary schools in the multi-denominational sector; if he will bring that sector into line with the mainstream of primary schools in terms of arrangements for its capital funding; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Qst.hpid: Mr. M. Higgins Mr. M. Higgins
Qst.Quest: if he will make a statement on the implementation of guarantees that he gave to schools under the umbrella of Educate Together and to the Galway school project in particular.
the proposals, if any, he has to meet with and address the concerns of an organisation (details supplied) which has been seeking a meeting with him; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

the meetings, if any, he has had with Educate Together in the period since 22 January 1998 when he announced an historic move on the question of capital funding for multi-denominational primary education; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education and Science (Mr. Martin) Micheál Martin
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Education and Science (Mr. Martin)
Speaker.P: I propose to take Questions Nos. 51, 69, 75 and 163 together.
I have arranged to meet Education Together on Tuesday next 27 October 1998 to discuss a number of issues of concern to the organisation.

Multi-denominational schools receive capital grant-aid on the same basis as denominational schools. Specifically in regard to the provision of sites for new schools it is currently a matter for the patron of the school, denominational or multi-denominational, to arrange for the provision of the site, except in the case of Gael-scoileanna.
When I met representatives of a multi-denominational school in Galway on 22 January last, I signalled to them my intention to change policy in regard to the provision of sites for new schools.

My announcement represents a significant policy change and consequently it has required detailed consultations and discussions prior to implementation. I hope to be in a position shortly to announce the details of my initiative.
