Qst.Quest: the plans, if any, he has to introduce multi-annual budgeting for the voluntary youth sector; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education and Science (Mr. Martin) Micheál Martin
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Education and Science (Mr. Martin)
Speaker.P: An overall multi-annual budgetary framework and arrangements for Government Departments are under consideration. It will not be possible to clarify the multi-annual budgetary situation for the voluntary youth sector until the overall multi-annual framework has been finalised by Government.

Qst.Quest: the degree to which psychological assessment is available in primary and post-primary schools; if he has received an indication of the requirements from representatives of school authorities and teachers unions; the degree to which the current and projected need is being met; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education and Science (Mr. Martin) Micheál Martin
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Education and Science (Mr. Martin)
Speaker.P: All second level schools are assigned to one of the psychologists employed by my Department. Nineteen psychologists are engaged in the post-primary sector.

The service to primary schools is still in the development stage, although there has been considerable expansion over the past 12 months. There are now 27 psychologists working in the sector. The psychological service is available to all primary schools designated as disadvantaged in the cities of Dublin, Cork and Limerick; all primary schools in County Tipperary South Riding and between 15 and 30 schools in each of the following counties: Clare, Cork, Dublin, Galway, Kerry, Kildare, Louth, Mayo, Meath, Offaly, Sligo, Tipperary North Riding and Wicklow.

The psychologists try to provide a balance between individual casework, including assessment work, and general support and development work in schools. They engage in casework as the resources of time and personnel allow.

I am aware that all the needs for assessments may not be met. It is my intention therefore that all schools should have ready access-to a psychological service through the establishment of a national educational psychological service which will be available to all primary and secondary schools as well as to preschool children. Plans for this service are included in the programme for Government.

In 1997, I set up a planning group to survey the current availability of psychological services to students in schools and to make recommendations to me on the developments that would be necessary in order to ensure effective provision in all areas. The planning group included representatives of all the partners in education, including school management authorities and teachers' organisations. It met frequently between October 1997 and June 1998. All members of the group availed of the opportunity to provide evidence of needs as well as their views on the proposed new psychological service. The planning group set up a technical working group to provide a detailed examination of the current availability of psychological services to children and young people and of the estimated needs for such services. This group included representatives of the major clients, including teachers and parents.

The report of the planning group has now been published. I launched it publicly on 15 September and have now set up an implementation group in my Department to plan the phased expansion of the psychological service to all schools.

Qst.Quest: the number of disadvantaged schools and of breaking the cycle schools which lost teachers in 1998 due to falling teacher numbers.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education and Science (Mr. Martin) Micheál Martin
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Education and Science (Mr. Martin)
Speaker.P: The information requested by the Deputy is being complied and will be forwarded to the Deputy shortly.

Qst.Quest: the guidelines, if any, he has issued or intends to issue to primary school principals regarding medical and insurance matters pertaining to the safe operation of the school; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education and Science (Mr. Martin) Micheál Martin
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Education and Science (Mr. Martin)
Speaker.P: Under the booklet, Constitution of Boards and Rules of Procedure for Boards of Management of National Schools, which was issued by my Department to all primary schools in 1997, boards of management are charged with the direct governance of primary schools.

Section 19(d) of that booklet points out that it is the duty of the board of management to put in place and maintain comprehensive insurance cover for the school. The board is obliged to ensure that all such assurances are effected and maintained as are necessary to safeguard the school, the board and the trustees against all public liability and against the consequences of negligence of any person employed by the board, or any servant or agent of the board, or any defect in the buildings, premises, furnishings or equipment of the school whereby loss or damage might result to any person in or upon the school premises.

In relation to medical matters, I can confirm that the health promotion unit of the Department of Health and Children issued a manual — Infection in Schools — A Manual for School Personnel — to all primary schools in 1994. The aim of this manual was to assist school personnel in differentiating between infections which are less serious and those which need medical attention, and to outline to schools basic infection control guidelines which should be in place in all schools. The manual was compiled under the auspices of a steering committee which included three representatives from this Department.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers - School Staffing.

Qst.hpid: Proinsias De Rossa Proinsias De Rossa
Qst.Quest: the steps, if any, being taken to deal with the issues of funding and staffing which have led to a one day industrial action by members of the INTO in a number of schools; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Qst.hpid: Mr. R. Bruton Mr. R. Bruton
Qst.Quest: if his attention has been drawn to the catalogue of service deficiencies in the primary education provisions set out by INTO in its submissions to Dáil Deputies; and his views on whether the provision which he has made falls short of the declared commitment to give priority to primary education.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education and Science (Mr. Martin) Micheál Martin
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Education and Science (Mr. Martin)
Speaker.P: I propose to take Questions Nos. 57 and 62 together.

While I am aware of the ongoing demands for increased resources for primary schools, I very much regret that the INTO considered it necessary to engage in selective industrial action in a number of schools. The Deputies will be aware that I consider that the action taken by the INTO was unjustifiable and impacted most adversely on the children in the schools concerned.

An Action Programme for the Millennium contains a commitment to give primary education a clear priority in the allocation of resources. I can assure the Deputies that, in the context of the 1999 Estimates, I am currently examining a range of options with a view to identifying the most appropriate ways to fulfil this commitment.

Since coming to office last year, I have made a number of changes which have improved the funding and staffing situation in schools. With regard to funding, the 1998 Estimates provided for an overall increase of almost 12 per cent in expenditure on primary education over the 1997 budget allocation. In this context, the 11 per cent increase in the standard rate of capitation grant at primary level represented an important step forward in the process of increasing capitation funding at primary level.

I have implemented a broad range of measures to increase the supply of fully trained teachers, including significantly increasing the intake into the colleges of education. This year alone, I ensured that over 1,000 places were available within the colleges of education. I intend to maintain this high intake level over the next few years. In addition, I have decided that, from 1 September 1998, all primary degree holders who also hold the Higher Diploma in Education will be recognised as fully trained for the purposes of providing substitution service provided that they have Irish to grade C at higher level leaving certificate standard or its equivalent.

I am determined to ensure that the demographic dividend arising over the next three years is retained in full in order that the pupil-teacher ratio may be still further reduced. I am especially anxious to continue the process of diverting resources towards pupils with special needs. In the current year I have allocated an additional 60 remedial teachers and 26 resource teachers to the primary system. It is my intention to continue to develop these services.
The recently launched early school leavers initiative, which is targeted on children in the eight to 15 years age group, involves an expenditure commitment of £3.62 million over the next two years.

MainHeading.P: In the circumstances, the Deputies will agree that the introduction of the above measures is indicative of the high priority the Government attaches to primary education, and clearly demonstrates its intent to honour its commitments in relation to this sector.

Qst.Quest: the proposals, if any, he has to reform the school transport system; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education and Science (Mr. Martin) Micheál Martin
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Education and Science (Mr. Martin)
Speaker.P: The school transport review committee undertook a comprehensive study of the entire school transport scheme. The committee's report, published in January 1998, was circulated to all relevant and interested parties for their views. The recommendations set out in the report dealt with a broad range of transport issues. The recommendations contained in the report do not necessarily reflect Government policy.

The contents of the report have given rise to extensive debate and a number of responses to the report have been received. Arising from this debate and responses, a number of proposals are currently under examination in my Department. Serious consideration will be given to these proposals before I make any final decisions or implement any reforms to the scheme.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers - School Staffing.

Qst.Quest: the consideration, if any, he has given to the case made by ASTI for a reduction in class sizes at second level; the additional staff or resources to be allocated to second level schools arising from the decision to increase the school leaving age to 16; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

the plans, if any, he has for a phased reduction in the ratio for appointing teachers to second level schools until levels of staff are adequate to allow schools to cater for all the needs of their students.

Qst.hpid: Mr. S. Ryan Mr. S. Ryan
Qst.Quest: the proposals, if any, he has to provide additional resources for secondary schools, in particular in the areas of pupil-teacher ratio and capitation payments; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education and Science (Mr. Martin) Micheál Martin
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Education and Science (Mr. Martin)
Speaker.P: I propose to take Questions Nos. 60, 73 and 79 together.

MainHeading.P: The teacher allocation to second level schools for a particular school year consists of the allocation warranted by the enrolment at the end of the preceding September together with approved ex-quota and concessionary posts. School authorities may apply for an increase in the approved allocation to cater for particular circumstances, including projected enrolment increases. This provision will continue to apply when the school leaving age is increased to 16.

The standard pupil-teacher ratio at second level is 19:1. When all pupils and teachers are taken into account, the actual pupil-teacher ratio at second level in the school year 1997-98 was of the order of 15.7:1. While final enrolment figures for the current school year have not as yet been compiled, projected enrolments and teacher numbers indicate an improvement in the position for the 1998-99 school year.

The question of reducing the ratio, and thereby reducing class sizes, must be considered in the context of available resources. The issue of increased capitation payments for schools will be looked at in the budgetary context and in light of available resources.

Qst.hpid: Mr. G. Mitchell Mr. G. Mitchell
Qst.Quest: the number of one teacher schools which received a second teacher in the current school year; and the number of one teacher schools with at least ten pupils which remain to receive the promised additional teacher.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education and Science (Mr. Martin) Micheál Martin
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Education and Science (Mr. Martin)
Speaker.P: A total of 67 schools which operated as one teacher units in the 1997-98 school year have received a second teacher for the current school year. There are currently 56 one teacher schools which had enrolments of ten or more pupils on 30 September 1997.

In the course of the current school year, I will continue to examine a range of options with a view to identifying the most appropriate way to fulfil the Government's commitments to the remaining one teacher schools as outlined in An Action Programme for the Millennium.

Qst.Quest: the way in which his Department can justify the shortfall in capitation grants at primary level in spite of the constitutional obligation on the State to provide free primary education.
the proposals, if any, he has to substantially increase the capitation payment of £50 for students at primary schools; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

if his attention has been drawn to the concerns expressed by the teachers' unions and the representatives of parents and school authorities in regard to the inadequacy of capitation grants; if he has received communications outlining the needs in this area; if he proposes to address the points raised; the way in which he proposes to meet this requirement in the short and medium term; if his attention has been drawn to the need to address this issue as a matter of urgency; his priorities in this regard for the next six months; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education and Science (Mr. Martin) Micheál Martin
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Education and Science (Mr. Martin)
Speaker.P: I propose to take Questions Nos. 63, 66 and 67 together.

My Department provides capitation grants towards the day-to-day running costs of primary schools. School authorities are required to supplement the capitation grant with a local contribution, which traditionally amounted to 25 per cent of the State grant. Since 1995 the local contribution has been frozen at £10 per pupil in the case of mainstream schools and at £9.50 per pupil in the case of schools designated as disadvantaged. In effect, therefore, the required local contribution has already fallen well below the traditional 25 per cent.

The Deputies will be aware that An Action Programme for the Millennium contains a commitment to give primary education a clear priority in the allocation of resources. I can assure the Deputies that, in the context of the 1999 estimates, I am currently examining a range of options, including the level of capitation rates to primary schools, with a view to identifying appropriate ways to fulfil this commitment.

The Government's commitment in this regard was clearly reflected in the 1998 Estimates, which provided for an overall increase of almost 12 per cent in expenditure on primary education. In this context, the 11 per cent increase in the standard rate of capitation grant represented an important step forward in the process of improving funding of the primary sector.

I can assure the Deputies that I am aware of the concerns of the education partners on this matter and I will continue to give priority to the issue of further increases in the capitation grant to primary schools.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers - Irish Language Teaching.

Qst.Quest: the research, if any, his Department is involved in, or is aware of, into the standards and methods of teaching Irish in primary schools; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education and Science (Mr. Martin) Micheál Martin
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Education and Science (Mr. Martin)
Speaker.P: In 1984 Institiúid Teangeolaíochta Éireann, ITÉ, the Irish Linguistics Institute published the results of tests carried out in the oral Irish proficiency of pupils in second, fourth and sixth classes in primary schools. The publication was entitled “Spoken Irish in Primary Schools”.

MainHeading.P: In 1988 ITÉ, with the co-operation of my Department's inspectorate, carried out observational research in 22 schools representing the broad range of linguistic, social and educational conditions under which Irish is taught at present. The results have been published in a number of journals and collections of essays.

In preparation for the new curriculum in Irish, the National Council for Curriculum and Assessment, NCCA, was directed to review the research literature on teaching Irish and on second language teaching generally in regard to methodology and course content. ITÉ was commissioned to carry out this research and it published two volumes of prototype lessons and course materials. These were used by the NCCA in drawing up a new curriculum in Irish which will be presented to me for adoption in the near future.

Qst.Quest: the legislative underpinning which he plans to give to the proposed national psychological service agency; the budget which will be required to meet the additional 131 psychologists and associated support staff required over the next five years; and his views on the recommendations in relation to resourcing.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education and Science (Mr. Martin) Micheál Martin
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Education and Science (Mr. Martin)
Speaker.P: The Education (No. 2) Bill, 1997, when enacted, will empower me to establish executive agencies to carry out functions in respect of support services. The definition of support services in the Bill specifically includes psychological services. When the Education (No. 2) Bill, 1997, is enacted I may then establish, by order, a national educational psychological service agency as proposed by the planning group I appointed to make recommendations for such a service. The order establishing the agency will include such provisions as I consider appropriate to defining the functions of the agency as well as provisions relating to the finances and staffing of the agency.

As recommended by the planning group I have established an implementation group of officials within my Department to prepare the detailed costings for the additional 131 psychologists, and the support staff, required over the recommended development period of five years beginning in 1999. The provision of an estimate of cost was not part of the remit of the planning group. The implementation group will also make the other preparatory arrangements for the establishment of the proposed agency and the initiation of its service.

I consider that the psychologist staffing and other support resources, as recommended by the planning group, are realistic. The group has provided a plan which includes clear purposes for an educational psychological service and which also includes a target for the development, within a reasonable period of time, of a service which can be more readily available to all students who need it.

Qst.Quest: if he has satisfied himself that adequate systems have been put in place to monitor progress towards key targets set out in the national anti-poverty strategy in relation to education.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education and Science (Mr. Martin) Micheál Martin
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Education and Science (Mr. Martin)
Speaker.P: The overall target of the national anti-poverty strategy in relation to educational disadvantage is to reduce and eliminate early school leaving at second level and to eliminate literacy and numeracy problems in early primary education.

My Department has a range of strategies in place to help prevent early school leaving. These include the development of early start centres; the allocation of additional resources to schools in disadvantaged areas; the Breaking the Cycle initiative; the home school community liaison scheme; curricular reforms to allow students to make choices relevant to their abilities and aptitudes; support for junior and senior centres for travellers; the free book scheme, and alleviation of examination fees, for necessitous pupils. Strategies in place are subject to ongoing monitoring and evaluation.

The primary curriculum is designed to achieve adequate levels of literacy and numeracy among all pupils. Monitoring of progress towards this objective is achieved through national surveys of achievement and participation in international comparative studies. The latest national survey of reading in primary schools was carried out in 1998 by my Department's inspectors in co-operation with the Educational Research Centre. The findings of the 1998 survey are being processed at present. In addition, Irish primary school pupils have participated in national and international assessments of mathematics performance. As the Deputy will be aware, plans for the introduction of a revised primary curriculum are well advanced. Assessment is an integral part of this process.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers - Third Level Places.

Qst.Quest: if his attention has been drawn to recent allegations suggesting that universities and other colleges were manipulating their quota of students in order that they could produce high entry points and claim a high quality image; if he has carried out an investigation into these allegations; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education and Science (Mr. Martin) Micheál Martin
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Education and Science (Mr. Martin)
Speaker.P: Admissions are a matter for individual universities under the Universities Act, 1997.
The points required for a course are a function of the number of places on offer and the number of applicants for these places.

MainHeading.P: The number of places is determined by the availability of resources and physical facilities. In some cases, such as medicine, an overall limit is imposed on the institution for policy reasons.

My Department has consulted with the Higher Education Authority about these allegations and has been advised by the Higher Education Authority that it is not aware of any evidence to support these allegations.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers - Guidance and Remedial Teachers.

Qst.hpid: Mr. R. Bruton Mr. R. Bruton
Qst.Quest: the number of additional guidance and remedial teachers provided at second level in the current school year.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education and Science (Mr. Martin) Micheál Martin
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Education and Science (Mr. Martin)
Speaker.P: The guidance and remedial allocations to second level schools have remained constant since 1995. At present there are 350 remedial and 567 guidance posts within the second level system.

In the school year 1997-98 enrolments stood at 368,400 and teacher numbers for that year were 23,558. In the current year projected enrolments indicate a reduction of about 4,000. Teacher numbers in the present year are broadly in line with those for 1997-98. In summary therefore the actual pupil-teacher ratio which stood at 15.64 in 1997-98 is anticipated to reduce further in the current school year.
The issue of additional resources for the second level sector is one which I will be discussing with the Minister for Finance in the context of this year's Estimates.

Qst.Quest: if the interim review group has completed its report and recommendations on Waterford Institute of Technology self-evaluation study; if it recommends the immediate delegation of qualification awarding authority to the institute; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education and Science (Mr. Martin) Micheál Martin
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Education and Science (Mr. Martin)
Speaker.P: I understand that the interim review group has completed a draft report on the self-evaluation study by Waterford institute of Technology and has furnished the institute with its observations on the study and its draft recommendations. A similar position applies with Cork Institute of Technology which was also being reported on by the group.

At present the group is considering the responses from Waterford and Cork Institutes of Technology to these observations and draft recommendations prior to finalising its report which will then be submitted to me.

Qst.Quest: the number of teaching posts which will become available in 1999 arising from the demographic dividend; the categories these posts will be allocated to; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education and Science (Mr. Martin) Micheál Martin
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Education and Science (Mr. Martin)
Speaker.P: At this early stage of the current school year it is not possible to determine the number of teaching posts which will become available next year arising from the demographic dividend.
In the circumstances, the categories to which available posts will be allocated cannot be anticipated at this time.

Qst.hpid: Proinsias De Rossa Proinsias De Rossa
Qst.Quest: if his Department will undertake a survey to establish the level of voluntary contributions paid by parents of children at both first and second level in view of the fact that this information is not available to his Department.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education and Science (Mr. Martin) Micheál Martin
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Education and Science (Mr. Martin)
Speaker.P: Voluntary contributions by parents and others are permissible under the free education scheme. The extent of such local fund raising by and on behalf of schools is determined by a range of socio-economic factors including the level of local initiative and the need for additional facilities and curriculum provision as perceived by parents and the wider local community.
In the same way, the state gives an capitation payment, currently 60 per cent, to schools designated as disadvantaged.

The benefits of a survey along the lines suggested by the Deputy are not clear. Local contributions towards education provision have long been a feature of Irish education and any move towards quantifying the amount of such contributions would require the purpose and parameters of the inquiry to be clarified. Distinguishing between essential and optional spending on the schools would be extremely difficult.

Qst.Quest: the proposals, if any, he has to extend the third level maintenance grant scheme to cover further categories of students studying outside the State; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education and Science (Mr. Martin) Micheál Martin
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Education and Science (Mr. Martin)
Speaker.P: I have no plans at present to extend the third level student support schemes to cover further categories of students studying outside the State.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers - Dyslexic Children.

Qst.Quest: the training, if any, provided to both primary and secondary school teachers to facilitate identifying children who suffer from dyslexia; the nature of the school service, if any, available to teachers who refer a child for assessment for dyslexia in consultation with the child's parents; and the guidelines, if any, his Department furnishes to teachers to address this problem.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education and Science (Mr. Martin) Micheál Martin
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Education and Science (Mr. Martin)
Speaker.P: Classroom teachers in primary and post-primary schools, in consultation with remedial teachers, have the lead responsibility for the identification and remediation of specific learning difficulties, including dyslexia.

My Department has supported courses in remedial education for many years. Since 1994, there has been a national programme of training for remedial teachers. At present, post-graduate courses for teachers at primary and post-primary levels are held in six centres in universities and in colleges of education. In the current academic year 99 primary teachers and 64 post-primary teachers are attending these courses.

These courses in remedial education are supported and directly funded by the in-career development unit of my Department. The syllabus includes training in the diagnosis and identification of reading difficulties and in appropriate techniques for remediation. In particular, there is a focus on the problem of specific learning difficulties, including dyslexia, in relation to diagnosis and pedagogy.

Many shorter courses for remedial and other interested teachers in specific learning difficulties have been supported financially by my Department. They have been mainly provided through the network of education centres, through teachers' organisations and through the programme of summer courses for primary teachers.

Remedial teachers may need to consult educational psychologists in respect of certain pupils who display marked specific learning difficulties. My Department provides an educational psychological service at present to all post-primary schools and to more than 700 primary schools. The psychologists provide assessments and advice to teachers and parents in respect of students with specific learning difficulties as the resources of time and personnel allow. My Department's psychologists are firmly committed to consultation with parents as an essential part of the assessment process.

I intend to improve access to such support by the provision of a national educational psychological service, which will be readily available to all schools. On 15 September of this year, I launched and endorsed the report of the planning group for this service. I have now set up a small implementation group within my Department to produce detailed proposals for the development of the psychological service, beginning in 1999. As an interim measure, my Department will shortly be recruiting a further ten psychologists.

MainHeading.P: Guidelines for teachers on addressing specific learning difficulty may be provided in the context of the training courses referred to. Teachers may also have access to advice on classroom management of learning disability by their district inspector and/or their area psychologist.

Qst.hpid: Mr. D. Carey Mr. D. Carey
Qst.Quest: the terms of reference of the liaison committee on the school curriculum formed between his Department and the Department of Arts, Heritage, Gaeltacht and the Islands; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education and Science (Mr. Martin) Micheál Martin
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Education and Science (Mr. Martin)
Speaker.P: As a result of bilateral discussions with my colleague, the Minister for Arts, Heritage, Gaeltacht and the Islands, a formal liaison committee has been set up between our two Departments and An Chomhairle Ealaíon, the Arts Council. The terms of reference of this committee are to assess the development and implementation of the school curriculum in the context of helping to ensure that the curriculum places more emphasis on cultural and artistic activities as promised in the programme for Government. This committee will have its first meeting in the near future.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers - White Paper on Science Policy.

Qst.hpid: Mr. J. O'Keeffe Mr. J. O'Keeffe
Qst.Quest: the plans, if any, he has to publish a White Paper on science policy.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education and Science (Mr. Martin) Micheál Martin
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Education and Science (Mr. Martin)
Speaker.P: I have no plans to publish a White Paper on science policy. A White Paper on Science, Technology and Innovation was published in 1996.

The Government has appointed a Minister of State at the Departments of Education and Science and Enterprise, Trade and Employment with responsibility for science and technology. The Minister of State has established a co-ordinating group comprising senior officials from the two Departments and the relevant state agencies to advise and assist him in developing and co-ordinating funding arrangements in relation to science and technology research.

In addition the Irish Council for Science, Technology and Innovation advises the Minister on a range of STI issues. The Minister also chairs an interdepartmental group of senior officials which advises on the co-ordination and prioritisation of State expenditure on science and technology.

Qst.Quest: if he will allocate additional funds in order that an additional tranche of projects can go ahead in view of the huge levels of applications for the early school leaver initiative.

Qst.hpid: Mr. R. Bruton Mr. R. Bruton
Qst.Quest: if he will allocate additional funds in order that an additional tranche of projects can go ahead in view of the huge level of applications for the early school leaver initiative.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education and Science (Mr. Martin) Micheál Martin
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Education and Science (Mr. Martin)
Speaker.P: I propose to take Questions Nos. 85 and 158 together.

A total of 14 project areas have been selected for inclusion under the present phase of the initiative. Funding amounting to £3.62 million is being made available to the initiative over the coming two years.

The initiative includes a project strand, a research strand and an evaluation strand. A management committee, comprising representatives of the Department and outside agencies, has been established to oversee the operation of the initiative. A projects co-ordinator was appointed on 1 August 1998 to support the selected projects and to co-ordinate the development of the programme. The objective of the pilot projects is to develop models of good practice with a view to their integration, after structured evaluation, into mainstream policy and practice.

The operation of the pilot phase of the initiative will be kept under ongoing review. The question of expanding the initiative will be considered in the light of experience with the models now being tested under the pilot phase. I am sure the Deputy would agree it would defeat the purpose of the research to mainstream an initiative before its effectiveness has been proven.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers - Specific Learning Difficulties.

Qst.Quest: his Department's definition of dyslexia, dyspraxia and attention deficit disorder; the number with each condition among the schoolgoing population as diagnosed by the psychologists of his Department; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education and Science (Mr. Martin) Micheál Martin
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Education and Science (Mr. Martin)
Speaker.P: The definitions of different disabilities used by the Department of Education and Science are those described and recommended in the Report of the Special Education Review Committee, 1993.

MainHeading.P: In Ireland the term “specific reading disability” has been officially adopted in preference to the term “dyslexia”. The definition of this condition derived from this report is that it is an impairment in reading, writing or spelling, the primary cause of which is not attributable to assessed ability being below the average range, defective sight or hearing, emotional factors, a physical condition or to any extrinsic adverse circumstances. Psychologists of my Department assess and diagnose and make recommendations in individual cases as referred to them in schools, but they do not gather statistical data on prevalence or incidence.

Dyspraxia and attention deficit disorder are not conditions that were defined in the Report of the Special Education Review Committee. These disabilities are generally diagnosed by medical specialists. Where children are diagnosed with these conditions and where there are accompanying difficulties in learning requiring special education, such is provided where resources permit.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers - Education of Traveller Children.

Qst.Quest: if he is monitoring the proportion of traveller children who are being retained to complete junior cycle and senior cycle at second level; and the progress, if any, made in improving retention in the past year.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education and Science (Mr. Martin) Micheál Martin
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Education and Science (Mr. Martin)
Speaker.P: The returns by schools to the post primary pupil database do not identify pupils form traveller families separately. Consequently, the exact numbers of traveller children who complete the junior cycle and the senior cycle at second level are not available.

It is estimated that the total number of traveller children attending post primary schools in the current school year is 650. The estimated figure for the 1997-98 school year is 500. It is estimated that 175 traveller children are enrolled in junior education centres this year. The estimated figure for 1997-98 is 200.

My Department has just put in place a pilot project called “The 8 to 15 Year Old Early School Leavers Initiative”. This will run in 14 project areas until June 2000. This project aims to develop effective strategies for preventing school drop out and for encouraging those who may have left school to return to education. It also aims to develop an effective system for tracking pupils through the education system.

When the project is completed, it is hoped to implement, on a nationwide basis, the strategies which will have been developed. It is important to point out that, while these will be of benefit in achieving higher retention rates among traveller children, they will apply to the whole school-going population.

My Department is a partner with Pavee Point in an Integra project which is working to design a strategy for data gathering, data analysis and decision making so as to facilitate access to education and training by travellers and to develop a suitable tracking system.

Qst.Quest: the research, if any, his Department is involved in, or is aware of, into the standard and methods of teaching Irish in second level schools and colleges; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education and Science (Mr. Martin) Micheál Martin
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Education and Science (Mr. Martin)
Speaker.P: It is planned that a major study will begin shortly in Institiúid Teangeolaíochta Éireann to determine the amount of Irish acquired by leaving certificate students on leaving school.

I am not aware of any current research which attempts to compare or evaluate different methods of teaching Irish on a large scale, but this type of research is no longer common. It is more usual nowadays for teachers to come together in smaller localised groups to conduct their own study of current practice and to experiment with new teaching methods and materials.

For a number of years now, work has been going on in collaboration between the curriculum development unit of the City of Dublin Vocational Education Committee and Institiúid Teangeolaíochta Éireann on teaching methods and materials for the foundation level courses at junior and leaving certificate. New materials are produced and piloted in 15 Dublin schools.

The Department is currently supporting a research project entitled “Gaeilge ag obair/Irish works sa scoil”. This involves a selection of second level schools. The aims of the project include the production of guidelines which school communities will find useful in helping to create an Irish-bilingual atmosphere. The project will focus, inter alia, on the school plan, the transition year, extra-curricular activities and school communication, internal and external.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers - Early Childhood Education.

Qst.Quest: the moneys he has designated to expand pre-school services funded by his Department which is recommended by the recent report on pre-school provision.
the reason for the delay in the publication of the report of the National Forum on Early Schooling; and the date on which the report was provided to his Department.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education and Science (Mr. Martin) Micheál Martin
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Education and Science (Mr. Martin)
Speaker.P: I propose to take Questions Nos. 89 and 90 together.
My Department currently provides £1,035 million to fund the pilot early start pre-school programme. My Department also provides funding for pre-school services for travellers.

MainHeading.P: The Government programme contains a commitment to provide a specific budget for pre-school education. As a first step to meeting this commitment, I have announced my intention to publish a White Paper, which will set out Government policy with regard to early childhood education. The question of funding for the extension of pre-school services will be considered in this context. The National Forum for Early Childhood Education, which I convened in March last, provided a focus for consultation with all of those with an interest in early childhood education.

The report on the forum, which was prepared by the independent secretariat to the forum, was received in my Department over the summer period. The arrangements for printing the report were then made by my Department. It is my intention to publish the report as soon as possible. However, I considered it inadvisable to publish it during the summer, when many of the persons and organisations with an interest in the matter would have been unavailable due to holidays. Pressure of other commitments, including, most particularly, legislative commitments, since the summer break has meant that I have not had the opportunity to publish the report over that period.
However, I assure the Deputy that I intend to publish the report at the earliest possible opportunity.

Qst.Quest: his views on the adequacy of provisions to support the delivery of primary education in the State by parties other than the State itself and the religious denominations; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education and Science (Mr. Martin) Micheál Martin
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Education and Science (Mr. Martin)
Speaker.P: In pursuance of the provisions of Articles 42 and 44 of the Constitution, the State provides for free primary education for children in national schools. The State discharges its obligation in this regard by recognising and funding privately-owned and publicly-owned schools. Many of these schools are operated by religious orders although, increasingly, schools may be of a multi-denominational nature.

The State also recognises that parents are constitutionally entitled to provide their children's education in their homes or in private schools and I acknowledge a number of private schools have been established for this purpose. However, such private schools are not recognised by the State and, consequently, do not receive funding from the State.

My main responsibility as Minister for Education and Science is to ensure there are sufficient places available to cater for the needs of pupils at primary level. I am satisfied the current provisions for recognition and funding of schools enables me to discharge this responsibility.

Qst.Quest: if he will lay before Dáil Éireann the full text of the report on remedial education teaching.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education and Science (Mr. Martin) Micheál Martin
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Education and Science (Mr. Martin)
Speaker.P: The report of the study of Remedial Education in Irish Primary Schools was received in my Department in August 1998. Arrangements are already being made for the publication of a summary report of the study and this will be made available to the members of the House and to the public generally.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers - Financial Services Regulation.

Qst.Dept: Tánaiste and Minister for Enterprise, Trade and Employment
Qst.hpid: Mr. G. Reynolds Mr. G. Reynolds
Qst.askee: Tánaiste and Minister for Enterprise, Trade and Employment
Qst.Quest: the structures, if any, her Department proposes to put in place to ensure that there is genuine transparency in the financial and insurance industries as opposed to the current position where breaches of current legislation can go unchecked if undetected by the media.

Qst.Dept: Tánaiste and Minister for Enterprise, Trade and Employment
Qst.hpid: Mr. G. Reynolds Mr. G. Reynolds
Qst.askee: Tánaiste and Minister for Enterprise, Trade and Employment
Qst.Quest: the procedures, if any, in place to ensure that the financial sector complies with existing guidelines in relation to ethics within this sector.

Speaker.hpid: Tánaiste and Minister for Enterprise, Trade and Employment (Ms Harney) Tánaiste and Minister for Enterprise, Trade and Employment (Ms Harney)
Speaker.NameTxt: Tánaiste and Minister for Enterprise, Trade and Employment (Ms Harney)
Speaker.P: : I propose to take Questions Nos. 93 and 94 together.

The Government has agreed this week to the creation of a new single regulatory authority for financial services. An implementation group is being established to process the work necessary to enable the Authority to be set up as soon as possible. This group will be asked to report back by 28 February 1999. Among the issues to be considered by the implementation group will be the responsibilities of the new Authority in connection with the relationships between financial undertakings and their customers.

The Deputy will be aware that my Department's responsibilities relate to the regulation of the insurance industry as well as to friendly societies and credit unions, company law and consumer protection.

I intend to introduce shortly life assurance transparency regulations. These regulations will provide, as of legal right, for understandable information on essential features or key areas connected with buying life assurance. The prime objectives in the formulation of such a regime are an end to over-complication in presentation of products, enhanced competition, end to misselling/confusion, realistic investment projections, transparency on charges and expenses, knowledge of with whom the consumer is dealing and redress through a firm statutory basis.

MainHeading.P: Under the Companies Act, 1990, I have responsibility for supervising the training and ethical standards of the accountancy profession, and I have taken a number of initiatives in the recent past to enhance my oversight role. These include requiring access for my Department to observe investigations by the accountancy bodies of disciplinary cases involving matters of public concern, more detailed annual reporting of their handling of disciplinary matters in general and the notification of company law breaches coming to their attention. I welcome the fact that some accountancy bodies are now taking steps to make their disciplinary proceedings more transparent. I should add for the Deputy's information that the Moriarty tribunal has been asked to make whatever broad recommendations it considers necessary or expedient for the effective regulation by professional accountancy bodies of their members' conduct.

Qst.Dept: Tánaiste and Minister for Enterprise, Trade and Employment
Qst.hpid: Mr. R. Bruton Mr. R. Bruton
Qst.askee: Tánaiste and Minister for Enterprise, Trade and Employment
Qst.Quest: the significance of the decision by a company (details supplied) to downgrade its Irish operation and move its software development capacity to India; the current employment in software development here; the way in which it has grown over the past five years; and the projections for its growth over the next five years.

Speaker.hpid: Tánaiste and Minister for Enterprise, Trade and Employment (Ms Harney) Tánaiste and Minister for Enterprise, Trade and Employment (Ms Harney)
Speaker.NameTxt: Tánaiste and Minister for Enterprise, Trade and Employment (Ms Harney)
Speaker.P: The company concerned is an Irish subsidiary of a British software services company. It sells its products mainly in the Asian, African and the middle Eastern markets. The company has decided to undertake some of its software development work in India. No redundancies are envisaged in their Irish operations.

Employment has increased in the software sector from 9,000 five years ago to about 20,000 this year. Further significant growth is expected over the next five years. The government has made significant commitments to facilitate this growth by providing substantial resources to increase the output of software graduates. In particular, I refer the Deputy to the introduction of the £250M Education Technology Investment Fund and the establishment of the business education and training partnership. I would also refer to the increased output of FÁS software and electronics courses. This will more than treble the numbers completing training on these FÁS courses over a three year period.
I am confident the result of the measures introduced will be to enhance Ireland's attraction as a location for further software activity.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers - Ferry Services.

Qst.askee: Minister for the Marine and Natural Resources
Qst.Quest: the number of occasions in the past 12 months that his Department has been contacted by the Department of Arts, Heritage, Gaeltacht and the Islands in respect of advice from his Department's surveyors regarding suitability of passenger ferries offered for tender purposes to and from offshore islands; and if his Department updates its register of these vessels on a regular basis and advises the Department of Arts, Heritage, Gaeltacht and the Islands of this information.

Qst.askee: Minister for the Marine and Natural Resources
Qst.Quest: the reason his Department does not have primary responsibility for awarding tenders to ferry passengers to and from offshore islands in view of the fact that this is the primary function of the licensing and certification procedures operated by his Department and safety of passengers is of paramount importance; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for the Marine and Natural Resources (Dr. Woods) Michael J. Woods
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for the Marine and Natural Resources (Dr. Woods)
Speaker.P: I propose to take Questions Nos. 97 and 98 together.

My Department's functions in relation to passenger vessels, under the Merchant Shipping Acts, are limited to the surveying, certification and licensing of any vessels that may be used or proposed to be used for the carriage of passengers.

MainHeading.P: All passenger vessels used for operating ferry services between offshore islands and the main-land are statutorily required to hold either a Passenger Vessel Safety Certificate — vessels carrying more than 12 passengers — or a Passenger Boat Licence — vessels carrying 12 or fewer passengers — issued by my Department. The primary function of this certification procedure is to ensure that the vessel is fit to operate, subject to any conditions that may be imposed upon it, and that the highest standards of safety are maintained.
Under the Acts it is a matter for the operators of such vessels, in the first instance, to approach the Marine Survey Office of my Department seeking such survey, certification or licensing.

My Department maintains a record of licensed vessels and makes that information available on request. As part of my ongoing commitment to increasing safety awareness, my Department is preparing proposals for the upgrading of the publication of this information with a view to achieving its widest possible dissemination.

The awarding of contracts in respect of ferry services to and from offshore islands is the responsibility of the Department of Arts, Heritage, Gaeltacht and the Islands. That Department makes funding available to secure ferry services to a number of islands and it is for that Department to satisfy itself on the social, economic and value for money aspects of any ferry operation it might decide to support. I understand that all tender documentation in respect of such operations includes a requirement that services should be operated using a suitably certified passenger vessel which meets the appropriate classification requirements of the Department of Marine and Natural Resources.

My Department is available to the Department of Arts, Heritage, Gaeltacht and the Islands, at all times, to offer advice as to the suitability of any vessel operating, or which it is proposed to operate. I cannot put a precise figure on the number of contacts, on the subject, made to my Department by the Department of Arts, Heritage, Gaeltacht and the Islands during the past 12 months. However, if the Deputy requires specific safety information in respect of any existing or proposed services, I will be glad to help him with his inquiries.

Qst.Quest: if the £500 million submission made by Iarnód Éireann for development of bus and rail services includes a proposal to develop the rail line for Athlone, County Westmeath, to Westport and Ballina, County Mayo; the nature and priority accorded to this area of line; if so, the costing in this regard; and if she will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Public Enterprise (Mrs. O'Rourke) Mary O'Rourke
Speaker.P: Earlier this year an independent safety review of railway infrastructure, covering jointed track, signalling and telecommunications, was carried out for Iarnród Éireann by A.D. Little. Following the submission of the consultants' report to my Department, I asked the CIE board to prepare a railway safety investment plan. That plan includes a track renewal programme for the Westport-Ballina line. It does not contain specific costings for the work proposed in relation to individual lines.

In March I commissioned a strategic review of all aspects of railway safety to be carried out by consultants, International Risk Management Services (IRMS). The review is nearing completion and will be published.
I will consider Iarnród Éireann's railway safety investment plan in conjunction with the IRMS review and make appropriate recommendations to the Government at an early date.

Speaker.P: As the Deputy will be aware, the Government's policy programme, An Action Programme for the Millennium, contains a number of commitments with regard to support both for families and also childcare.
With regard to childcare, in my budget speech last December I said:

It is not possible to introduce all the new measures one would wish in a single budget. I have examined carefully the possibility of a tax relief on childcare at the standard rate of tax but have decided not to proceed with it this year. MainHeading.Title: Written Answers - Cancer Screening Programme.

Qst.Quest: the waiting lists in the Dublin area for mammography services; the plans, if any, he has for the development of the service; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Health and Children (Mr. Cowen) Brian Cowen
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Health and Children (Mr. Cowen)
Speaker.P: The total number of women awaiting mammograms in the five major Dublin hospitals dealing with breast cancer, Mater, Beaumont, St. James's, St. Vincent's and the Adelaide and Meath Hospital, Dublin incorporating the National Children's Hospital, is approximately 1,700.

The average waiting time for routine referrals, that is, those which are not considered to be medically urgent, varies between four and eight weeks. Urgent appointments are normally seen within a few days of referral.

MainHeading.P: Routine or asymptomatic cases are dealt with as soon as possible, but must be subject to careful prioritisation. In view of the demands placed on mammography services, some hospitals may refer asymptomatic women to their general practitioner for a further assessment of priority. Hospitals review their caseload regularly, to ensure that women with an urgent cause for concern are seen without delay. The criteria for urgent cases include the existence of a breast lump, previous family history of breast cancer or other high risk indicators.

Where a woman is concerned at the length of time she has to wait for a mammography, she can ask her general practitioner to discuss her case with a consultant radiologist, who decides upon the priority of cases.

I am committed to developing mammography services in line with the principles of the national cancer strategy. In the Eastern Health Board area, the regional directors of cancer services are preparing proposals for the further development of services for the treatment of cancer, including breast cancer.

In addition to the provision of mammography services, work is continuing on the introduction of a formal breast screening programme aimed at detecting breast cancer in asymptomatic women. Phase one of the programme comprises the Eastern, Midland and North Eastern Health Board areas. I am committed to starting the screening programme as soon as possible. To this end I have approved funding to date of £2 million to cover the start-up costs and minor capital equipment needs of the programme. In addition, I recently approved a capital allocation of £1.035 million towards the refurbishment of 36 Eccles Street, Mater Hospital, as a screening and assessment unit and also as headquarters of the programme, and a capital allocation of £897,750 towards the construction of screening unit facilities at St. Vincent's Hospital. The existing breast clinic at St. Vincent's Hospital is due to be completely upgraded as part of Phase One of the £50 million general redevelopment programme approved for the hospital.

A key determinant regarding the start-up date for the breast screening programme will be the recruitment of the relevant consultant and support staff, advertisements for which were recently placed in the national press. Once the relevant staff are ready to take up their appointments we should be in a position to start the programme.

Qst.askee: Minister for Social, Community and Family Affairs
Qst.Quest: if he will allow people on carer's allowance to work up to 20 hours per week in cases where a family member can look after the person similar to the situation in relation to invalidity pension; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Social, Community and Family Affairs (Mr. D. Ahern) Dermot Ahern
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Social, Community and Family Affairs (Mr. D. Ahern)
Speaker.P: The qualifying conditions for the carer's allowance differ from those applying to the invalidity pension. One of the qualifying conditions for receipt of invalidity pension is that the pensioner must be permanently incapable of working. Accordingly, recipients of invalidity pension are not, in general, allowed to work.

However, with the prior approval of the Department, invalidity pensioners are allowed to engage in occupational training or work of a rehabilitative or therapeutic nature. There are no earnings or time limits applying to such training or work. These measures are designed to encourage and facilitate invalidity pensioners who wish to try and re-enter the workforce.

The carer's allowance is a social assistance scheme which provides an income maintenance payment to people who are providing elderly or incapacitated pensioners and certain persons with disabilities with full-time care and attention, and whose incomes fall below certain limits.

In its Action Programme for the Millennium, the Government is committed to progressively relaxing the qualifying criteria for the carer's allowance to ensure that more carers can get the benefit, and increasing the value of the allowance in real terms. In line with these commitments, an overall review of the carer's allowance has been completed and was published earlier this month.

One of the proposals put forward in the review concerns the relaxation of the full-time care and attention requirements to allow carers to undertake ten hours part-time work per week having due regard to the care recipients' needs. This would be a further extension of the relaxation of these rules earlier in 1998 which allowed carers to attend educational or training courses or participate in voluntary or community based activities, for around ten hours per week, provided that the carer makes adequate provision for the care recipient in his-her absence.
This proposal, and the other proposals contained in the review, will be considered in a budgetary context in the light of available resources.

Qst.Quest: the type of turf cutting excluded under the special areas of conservation on County Roscommon bogs; and the location of these bogs.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Arts, Heritage, Gaeltacht and the Islands (Miss de Valera) Síle de Valera
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Arts, Heritage, Gaeltacht and the Islands (Miss de Valera)
Speaker.P: The EU Habitats Directive prohibits significant damage occurring to the relevant habitats and species. In cases of raised bogs, turf cutting damages the habitat. I confirmed last March that no turf cutting would be permitted in raised bog areas proposed for designation as special areas of conservation as and from the beginning of next year. The specific areas proposed for designation have been published and publicly notified and maps are available to be inspected locally in the offices of the local authority, the farm development service, Teagasc and with the regional Manager of Dúchas, my Department's Heritage Service.

A number of options, including compensation, relocation to another site, sale of plots, or sale of turbary rights are available to turf cutters who are required to discontinue cutting in proposed SACS. These options may be followed up with Dúchas, the Heritage Service of my Department.

The bogs concerned in County Roscommon are officially known as Bellanagare Bog, Carrowbehy-Caher Bog, Cloonchambers Bog, Derrina Bog, Cloonshanville Bog, Corliskea-Trien-Cloonfelliv Bog, Lough Forbes Complex and Derrynabrock Bog.

Qst.askee: Minister for Justice, Equality and Law Reform
Qst.Quest: his views on whether the 1951 UN Convention on Refugees is out of date having regard to the post cold war political situation in Europe; and if he will confirm that Irish input into the framing of an EU consensus on asylum will emphasise the protection of refugees themselves rather than simply seeking to protect Europe from refugees.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Justice, Equality and Law Reform (Mr. O'Donoghue) John O'Donoghue
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Justice, Equality and Law Reform (Mr. O'Donoghue)
Speaker.P: I assume that the Deputy's question is based on proposals contained in the EU Presidency strategy paper on Immigration and asylum policy.
The position is that the paper in question, which has been tabled by the Austrian EU Presidency is at a preliminary stage of consideration in the EU Council framework.

Following the initial preliminary consideration of the paper, the Austrian Presidency agreed to revise it to take account of the views expressed by the member states. As the revised paper has only recently been received, it is still under consideration in my Department. However, I can reassure the Deputy that in considering any modifications to asylum law my priority is to ensure that persons genuinely in need of international protection will receive it.
I would also add that the agenda set by the Treaty of Amsterdam in the field of asylum over the next five years must specifically be in accordance with the Geneva Convention.

Qst.askee: Minister for Tourism, Sport and Recreation

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Tourism, Sport and Recreation (Dr. McDaid) James McDaid
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Tourism, Sport and Recreation (Dr. McDaid)
Speaker.P: The pilot initiative on tourism and the environment arose from the mid-term review of the operational programme for tourism, 1994-99. The objective of the initiative is to promote and support tourism projects of a pilot or demonstration nature which will contribute to knowledge and understanding of best practice in terms of sustainable tourism and the environment. European Regional Development Fund funding of 3 MECU, approximately IR£2.4 million is available for the initiative under the normal commitment and expenditure deadlines which apply under the operational programme.

A selection committee, chaired by an official of my Department, was established by the monitoring committee for the operational programme for the purpose of selecting projects for funding. It held its first meeting on 25th March 1998. An advertisement appeared in the three national daily newspapers on 2 and 3 April 1998 inviting applications under the initiative to be submitted to either Bord Fáilte or Shannon Development, as appropriate.

I announced details of the projects on 13 September 1998, and I will arrange for a copy of the press release to be forwarded to the Deputy.

Qst.hpid: Mr. M. Higgins Mr. M. Higgins
Qst.Quest: the decisions taken during 1998 to alter previous decisions in relation to individual capital projects in the technological sector; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education and Science (Mr. Martin) Micheál Martin
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Education and Science (Mr. Martin)
Speaker.P: The capital programme for the technological education sector comprises a broad range of projects at various stages of development. The programme, as the Deputy is aware, is implemented on a rolling basis.

In addition to the ongoing capital provision of around £25 million per annum for the technological sector, funding for capital projects has been increased very significantly in 1998 with the aid of the additional moneys under the Scientific and Technological Education (Investment) Fund. The Fund, which I made a priority on coming into Government, provides for an investment of £250 million over the period 1998 to 2000, is a clear statement of this Government's seriousness in addressing key educational issues which impact on our economic performance, and represents the largest single capital investment programme ever introduced by a Minister for Education.

The fund, which will provide a total of £250 million of public sector investment over three years, has three main objectives: to review, extend and modernise the infrastructure of third level institutions, particularly in the technological sector; to develop new areas of activities where emerging skills needs have been identified and to invest in promoting innovation to maintain and further our economic growth.

To facilitate the implementation of an increased range of projects under the Fund with maximum speed, I arranged that the first tranche of the fund provision, i.e. £100 million, be included in my Department's Estimates for this year. This provision is in addition to my Department's normal capital estimates.

Such a major increase in capital investment in the technological sector (among others) would of necessity require a review of decisions previously made in relation to the prioritisation of projects, and allocation of funds, in consultation with the institutes concerned. Arising from this process, it has been possible to bring forward many projects that would otherwise have been deferred, and to increase the size and scope of other eligible projects.
If the Deputy requires any information in relation to specific capital projects in the technological sector, I will, of course, make arrangements to provide it.

Qst.hpid: Mr. M. Higgins Mr. M. Higgins
Qst.Quest: the proposals, if any, he has to rectify an anomaly (details supplied) in the third-level student support scheme for persons under 23 years of age; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education and Science (Mr. Martin) Micheál Martin
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Education and Science (Mr. Martin)
Speaker.P: The higher education grant schemes operate under the Local Authorities (Higher Education Grants) Acts, 1968 to 1992. These Acts define a mature student to mean a person “of not less than 23 years of age, or such other age as may stand specified for the time being in regulations made by the Minister with the consent of the Minister for Finance, who have secured places in approved institutions and have reached that age on 1 January, or such other date as may be prescribed from time to time by the Minister with the consent of the Minister for Finance, in the year of entry to such institutions”. The Acts further provide, inter alia, for the making of grants to mature students whose means and those of their parents, where the mature students are dependent on their parents, and the means of their spouses, if any, do not exceed prescribed limits.

Under the terms of the higher education grants schemes, mature students are categorised as either independent mature students or mature students dependent on parents. An independent mature student is defined to mean a mature student who was not ordinarily resident at home with his or her parents from the October preceding their entry to an approved course. Independent mature students are deemed to be self-supporting and are assessed without reference to either their parents' income or address.

When assessing the means of students other than mature students, the Acts specify that the students' means and those of their parents or guardians must be below a prescribed limit. This provision requires that parental income be taken into account irrespective of the individual circumstances in any case where the student is not a mature student.
I appreciate the difficulties that these provisions can give rise to in individual cases, such as those outlined by the Deputy. I have asked my Department to keep this issue under review.

Qst.Quest: the plans, if any, he has to increase the level of capitation grant to primary schools in view of the concerns expressed by parents and teachers; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education and Science (Mr. Martin) Micheál Martin
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Education and Science (Mr. Martin)
Speaker.P: The Deputy will be aware that An Action Programme for the Millennium contains a commitment to give primary education a clear priority in the allocation of resources. I can assure the Deputy that, in the context of the 1999 Estimates, I am currently examining a range of options, including the level of capitation rates to primary schools, with a view to identifying appropriate ways to fulfil this commitment.

The Government's commitment in this regard was clearly reflected in the 1998 Estimates, which provided for an overall increase of almost 12 per cent in expenditure on primary education. In this context, the 11 per cent increase in the standard rate of capitation grant represented an important step forward in the process of improving funding of the primary sector.
I assure the Deputy that I will continue to give priority to the issue of further increases in the capitation grant to primary schools.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers - Breaking the Cycle Scheme.

Qst.Quest: if the current class numbers in the junior infants, Plás Mhuire boys national school, Dorset Street, Dublin 7, is in breach of the breaking the cycle guidelines; and, if so, if he will assist the school in this regard.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education and Science (Mr. Martin) Micheál Martin
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Education and Science (Mr. Martin)
Speaker.P: Schools included in the urban dimension of the breaking the cycle scheme, including the school mentioned by the Deputy, are required to operate maximum class sizes of 15 pupils in all junior classes. For the purpose of the scheme, junior classes include all classes from junior infants to second class.

Schools included in the scheme, including the school mentioned by the Deputy, have been allocated adequate staffing levels to enable them to comply with the maximum class size requirement in all junior classes.

Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Education and Science (Mr. Martin)

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers - Psychological Service.

Qst.Quest: the number of educational psychologists assigned to each county of designated inspectorial areas; if he has satisfied himself with the availability of a psychological service at primary school level; the plans, if any, he has to improve the situation; and if his attention has been drawn to the fact that there is a dispute as to whose responsibility it is.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education and Science (Mr. Martin) Micheál Martin
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Education and Science (Mr. Martin)
Speaker.P: All post-primary schools in the country are assigned to one of the psychologists employed by my Department. A total of 19 psychologists are currently engaged in the post-primary sector, giving an average of less than one psychologist per county.

The service to primary schools is still in the development stage. All schools designated as disadvantaged in the cities of Dublin, Cork and Limerick and all schools in County Tipperary South Riding are assigned to one of my Department's psychologists. During the past year, it has been possible to expand the psychological service to primary schools. Between 20 and 30 schools in each of the following counties has been added to the list of those served: Clare, Cork, Dublin, Galway, Kerry, Kildare, Louth, Mayo, Meath, Offaly, Sligo, Tipperary North Riding, Wicklow.

MainHeading.P: I am aware of the need for all schools to have ready access to a psychological service. I intend therefore to establish a national educational psychological service which will be available to all primary and secondary schools as well as to pre-school children. Plans for this service were included in the programme for Government.

The report of the planning group for this service has now been completed. I launched it publicly on 15 September. The report examined the current availability of psychological services to children and young people, and has made recommendations as to the developments which will be necessary in order to ensure effective provision in all areas. I have now set up an implementation group in my Department to plan the phased expansion of the psychological service to all schools.

In the past, the lead responsibility for providing a psychological service to primary schools rested with the health boards and with voluntary agencies under their aegis. I am aware that psychologists employed by some of these bodies have withdrawn or have announced their intention to withdraw from providing psychological assessments for educational purposes. This is in order that they may focus on children who need intensive therapy and family support. There may, therefore, be temporary difficulties in areas where my Department does not as yet provide a psychological service.

Children in schools need access to both clinical and educational psychological services, which will work in close collaboration with one another. For this reason, the Department of Health and Children was represented on the planning group for the new national educational psychological service. Implementation of the report will proceed in close consultation with the health authorities in order to ensure an orderly transfer of responsibilities where this is felt to be necessary. Meanwhile, the health board programme managers have been supplied with a list of those schools served by my Department's psychological service and there will be constant and close liaison at local level.
