MainHeading.Title: Written Answers - Post Leaving Certificate Courses.

Qst.Quest: if he will increase the income level for assessment for grant-aid for post leaving certificate courses or have the assessment based on net rather than gross income in view of the problems facing parents paying for these courses; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education and Science (Mr. Martin) Micheál Martin
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Education and Science (Mr. Martin)
Speaker.P: The programme for Government An Action Programme for the Millennium provides a commitment to the introduction of equitable support for students attending post-leaving certificate courses. I have honoured this commitment with the introduction of a maintenance grants scheme for students attending PLC courses in the current academic year. The grants will be means tested and the rates of grant, income limits, and other criteria for eligibility will be similar to those, which apply to the third level student support schemes.

The assessment of means under the third level student support schemes and the new PLC maintenance grants scheme is based on gross income with certain deductions for specified social welfare and health board payments. Any proposal to move to a means assessment system based on net income would have significant financial implications in addition to equity issues which would have to be addressed.

MainHeading.P: It has been the practice in recent years to increase the reckonable income limits in line with movements in the average industrial wage. The figures are provided by the Central Statistics Office and are computed in each case to March of the previous year. The average industrial wage increase for the period March 1996 to March 1997 was 3.2 per cent. The reckonable income limits for the 1998-99 academic year were therefore increased by 3.2 per cent. These increased reckonable incomes are being used for the PLC maintenance grants scheme.

It has also been the practice in recent years to increase maintenance grants in line with inflation as measured by the change in the Consumer Price Index for the period mid-February to mid-February each year. The inflation figure as provided by the Central Statistics Office for the period mid-February 1997 to mid-February 1998 was 1.7 per cent. The value of the maintenance grants was therefore increased by 1.7 per cent for the 1998-99 academic year.

This increase was also applied to the allowance by which the income limits may be increased in respect of other family members pursuing a course of study. The definition of eligible courses in this regard has also been extended to include those family members attending a recognised PLC course, student nurse training or student Garda training, those participating in certain CERT courses and those attending full time Teagasc courses in an agricultural college. In such cases the reckonable income limits are increased by £2,060 where there are two such children, £4,120 where there are three, and so on by increments of £2,060.

I am committed to ongoing improvements in the student support schemes, including increasing the value of maintenance grants and increasing the income limits as resources permit. The Deputy will appreciate that such improvements must have regard to overall resource constraints and competing demands in the education sector.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers - Learning Disabilities.

Qst.Quest: the assistance, counselling advice or grants available to a child with dyslexia in sixth class primary school; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education and Science (Mr. Martin) Micheál Martin
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Education and Science (Mr. Martin)
Speaker.P: The educational needs of primary pupils with specific learning disability are generally capable of being met within the ordinary school system, with the assistance, where appropriate, of a remedial teacher. Fully qualified primary school teachers are trained to deal with a variety of reading problems, including those which are accompanied by perceptual difficulties. In addition, the special training programme for remedial teachers includes a module on specific learning disability.
I recently allocated an additional 60 remedial teachers to primary schools. The total number of remedial teachers in place at primary level now stands at 1,302.

MainHeading.P: Where more serious cases of difficulty arise, provision is made in one of four special schools dedicated to the needs of such children. Three of these schools are located in Dublin and one in Cork. Special classes have also been established in a number of primary schools in areas where a need for such classes has been identified. There are six such classes in place at present.

The pupil-teacher ratio applicable in special schools and special classes catering for these children is 11:1. Pupils attending these facilities also attract special capitation funding at a rate of £253 for children under 12 years and £413 for children of 12 years or over.

My Department also provides an educational psychological service which is currently available to more than 700 primary schools. The psychologists provide assessments and advice to teachers and parents in respect of students with specific learning disability. The advice of my Department's Inspectorate is also available to schools catering for children with specific learning disability. The needs of children with specific learning disability are kept under ongoing review to ensure the best possible level of response to their needs.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers - University Accommodation.

Qst.hpid: Mr. R. Bruton Mr. R. Bruton
Qst.Quest: if the capacity of buildings in University College Cork has expanded to keep pace with the growing student numbers at the college; and the way in which the pupil to space ratio compares with other colleges and international standards.

Qst.hpid: Mr. R. Bruton Mr. R. Bruton
Qst.Quest: the plans, if any, he has to fund significant capital developments at University College Cork in view of the current requirement to use rented space away from campus and to cancel tutorials in several facilities for lack of space.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education and Science (Mr. Martin) Micheál Martin
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Education and Science (Mr. Martin)
Speaker.P: I propose to take Questions Nos. 174 and 175 together.

MainHeading.P: I have been aware for some time of the pressure on space in the university and since coming into office I have taken significant action to alleviate the problem. The recently opened applied business and languages building, O'Rahilly Building, has made a major contribution in improving the situation. The new building adds approximately 10 per cent to the overall spatial resources of the University and constitutes a major increment in the available level of technology and research accommodation. In total, the building provides an additional 500 computer stations, 650 seminar-tutorial places, 1,450 teaching-research places for students, 225 staff places and a services social area for 100 people. In addition, as an initial measure, I have already allocated £5 million from the Scientific and Technological Education (Investment) Fund for an extension to the O'Rahilly Building which will provide a further 500 undergraduate places. I have also directed my Department to allocate funds in the order of £2 million to be made available on an incremental basis to facilitate the development of the Good Shepherd Convent premises. When completed, it will accommodate the Departments of Applied Social Sciences, Music and Adult and Continuing Education, thus further alleviating the pressure on space.

At present the university rents space in properties, the majority of which are in close proximity to the main campus or the University facilities at the Lee Maltings and North Mall. I can assure the Deputy that the Government will continue to give the alleviation of space problems at UCC a high priority.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers - Student Grants.

Qst.hpid: Mr. R. Bruton Mr. R. Bruton
Qst.Quest: the reason for the cut from £300 to £250 in the recommended grant to students under the hardship fund; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education and Science (Mr. Martin) Micheál Martin
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Education and Science (Mr. Martin)
Speaker.P: The disadvantaged fund, which was established in 1994, comprises two elements, namely, the hardship fund and the special fund for students with disabilities. The objective of the hardship fund is to assist, in a sensitive and compassionate manner, students who might otherwise, because of financial reasons, suffer severe hardship or be unable to continue their third level studies.

MainHeading.P: The administration of this fund is devolved to the third level institutions. The allocation to the university sector is made through the Higher Education Authority and to the institutes of technology and the teacher training colleges directly from my Department. The allocations are based on total undergraduate enrolments in the previous academic year. College authorities are urged to supplement the fund from their own resources or from private sources.

The third level colleges have been advised to nominate one individual to administer the fund and final decisions should be taken by a small group appointed by the college authority. My Department does not recommend a specific allocation per student. However, I have asked my officials to request information on the issue and to examine if the objectives of the fund are being met.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education and Science (Mr. Martin) Micheál Martin

The primary pupil-teacher ratio is computed at national level rather than at regional or county level. Accordingly, it is not possible to provide details of the pupil-teacher ratio which pertains to any specific location.

The national pupil-teacher ratio at primary level in the 1997-98 school year was 21.7:1. While the pupil teacher ratio has declined significantly in recent years at primary level, the Government is committed to improving the ratio still further. Qst.Quest: if he will quantify the requirement for psychological assessment in the various first and second level schools in Kildare north; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education and Science (Mr. Martin) Micheál Martin
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Education and Science (Mr. Martin)
Speaker.P: All post-primary schools in County Kildare are assigned to one of the psychologists employed by my Department. The service to primary schools has, during the past year, been expanded to a number of primary schools in the county. In north Kildare, the six primary schools in Leixlip now have access to the psychological service.

The psychologists visit schools on a regular basis and consult with principals and other staff about the needs for psychological support, including assessments. Together they establish priorities for the work of the psychologists in the schools. The psychologists do not keep formal waiting lists, but over the past year all those children referred to them for assessment by the schools in north Kildare have been seen or are about to be seen by one of the psychologists.

I am aware that the number of referrals made may not necessarily reflect the number of students requiring psychological support. During 1997, I established a planning group to advise me on the setting up of a national educational psychological service. The planning group, assisted by a technical working group, made a detailed estimate of the number of appropriate referrals for psychological support that might generally be expected in any area. The estimate was that over a period of time 11.2 per cent of the school population might require such support.

The report of the planning group for the service has now been published. I launched it publicly on 15 September. The report examined the current availability of psychological services to children and young people and has made recommendations as to the developments that will be necessary in order to ensure effective provision in all areas. I have now set up an implementation group in my Department to plan the phased expansion of the psychological service to all schools so that the estimated level of need may be met.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers - Psychological Service.

Qst.Quest: the degree to which psychological assessment is available in first and second level schools; the plans if any, he has to augment this service in line with documented and requested requirements; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education and Science (Mr. Martin) Micheál Martin
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Education and Science (Mr. Martin)
Speaker.P: All second level schools in the country are assigned to one of the psychologists employed by my Department. Nineteen psychologists are currently engaged in the post-primary sector.

MainHeading.P: The service to primary schools is still in the development stage. All schools designated as disadvantaged in the cities of Dublin, Cork and Limerick and all schools in County Tipperary South Riding are assigned to one of my Department's psychologists. During the past year, it has been possible to expand the psychological service to primary schools. There are now 27 psychologists working in the primary sector. Between 20 and 30 schools in each of the following counties has been added to the list of those served: Clare, Cork, Dublin, Galway, Kerry, Kildare, Louth, Mayo, Meath, Offaly, Sligo, Tipperary North Riding and Wicklow.

The psychologists try to provide a balance between individual casework, including assessment work, and general support and development work in schools. They engage in casework as the resources of time and personnel allow.

I am aware that all the needs for assessments may not be met at present. It is my intention that all schools should have ready access to a psychological service through the establishment of a national educational psychological service which will be available to all primary and secondary schools as well as to pre-school children. Plans for this service are included in the Programme for Government.

The report of the planning group for this service has now been completed. I launched it publicly on 15 September. The planning group set up a technical working group to provide a detailed examination of the current availability of psychological services to children and young people and of the estimated needs for such services. The report of the planning group includes recommendations as to the developments that will be necessary in order to ensure effective provision in all areas. I have now set up an implementation group in my Department to plan the phased expansion of the psychological service to all schools.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers - School Secretarial and Caretaking Services.

Qst.Quest: further to Parliamentary Question No. 101 of 15 October 1998, his views on whether it is equitable that the salaries of secretaries and caretakers employed by vocational schools and community colleges with an enrolment in excess of 250 students are met in full by his Department whereas the salary costs of other schools of even greater student numbers and similar salary costs are not; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education and Science (Mr. Martin) Micheál Martin
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Education and Science (Mr. Martin)
Speaker.P: The way in which resources are provided to second level schools reflects the different management and ownership arrangements for vocational schools and community colleges, community and comprehensive schools and voluntary secondary schools. Consequently, direct comparison between the different sectors is difficult.

MainHeading.P: The financial allocations for vocational schools and community colleges are made to the vocational education committees as part of a block grant which also covers the VEC overheads and other activities apart from the second level programme. Voluntary secondary schools are funded on a per capita basis based upon enrolments while the annual budget for community and comprehensive schools takes into account factors which vary from school to school.

Current provision for caretaking and secretarial services in schools derive from commitments made under the Programme for Economic and Social Progress and is consistent with the manner in which financial allocations are made to each type of school.
In general, all schools with enrolments of 200 or more are entitled to assistance under the programme. The position in relation to each sector is as follows.

The allocation of caretaking and secretarial posts in vocational education sector is made on a scheme wide basis. It is a matter for each vocational education committee to deploy the staff as it sees fit. However, most schools in this sector have the services of a full-time caretaker and a secretary. Community and comprehensive schools have a full-time secretary and caretaker and schools with an enrolment in excess of 500 pupils have two full-time secretaries. Secondary schools with enrolments of 200 or more are in receipt of additional per capita grants towards the provision of caretaking and secretarial services, subject to maximum of £8,750 for caretaking and £10,500 in the case of secretarial services. The manner in which these services are provided is a matter for individual schools.

I recognise there are anomalies and inconsistencies between the different sectors. The matter of equity of funding between the various sectors at second-level is currently being examined by a steering group on funding. Under its terms of reference, the group will draw up a recommended funding framework designed to ensure equal treatment for different schools within the second level sector while taking account of the needs of these different schools.

Qst.Quest: if he will increase the capitation grant to allow primary schools to meet the full cost of their secretarial and caretaker salaries.
his views on whether a maximum grant of £7,500 is sufficient to meet the pay costs for caretaker or secretarial staff of a large primary school; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education and Science (Mr. Martin) Micheál Martin
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Education and Science (Mr. Martin)
Speaker.P: I propose to take Questions Nos. 190 and 191 together.

MainHeading.P: Arising from the Programme for Economic and Social Progress (PESP), a scheme was introduced in 1992 whereby my Department provides additional capitation grants for primary schools towards the cost of caretaking and clerical services.

Under the PESP scheme, schools receive grants of £30 per pupil (£15 per pupil in respect of each service), to a maximum of £15,000 per annum, which are paid as additions to the standard per capita grant. The scheme by its nature is flexible and gives boards of management full discretion as to the level and extent of the services to which the grants are to be applied.

Since its introduction in 1992, the scheme of additional capitation grants to schools in respect of such services has been expanded in line with under-takings given in the PESP. The priority has been to extend the scheme in the first instance to schools which have no caretaking or clerical provision already. In this regard the scheme has been extended to include more schools by reducing the qualifying enrolment threshold to its current figure of 195 pupils, with an ultimate target of providing additional capitation grants to all primary schools with 100 pupils or more.

I wish to assure the Deputy that I remain committed to improvements in the provision of additional assistance to schools for caretaking and clerical services and the position of schools which are currently in receipt of the maximum grant available under the scheme will be examined in the context of any improvements to the scheme which may be implemented in the future.

Qst.Quest: the number of expulsions from primary schools for each of the years from 1996 to date.
the number of expulsions from secondary schools for each of the years from 1996 to date.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education and Science (Mr. Martin) Micheál Martin
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Education and Science (Mr. Martin)
Speaker.P: I propose to take Questions Nos. 192 and 193 together.

Schools are not required to advise my Department of cases where children are expelled or otherwise excluded from schools and, accordingly, I am not in a position to supply the Deputy with the information he has requested.

It is my intention to establish a mechanism for the purpose of tracking all students in primary and second level schools. This matter is among the issues being addressed in the context of the new legislation on school attendance and educational welfare.

In addition, the eight to 15 years early school leavers initiative will involve the development of a tracking template-pupil data base for use in primary and second level schools which will provide an ongoing tracking service of all pupils in schools.
